video.title: Intermediate Python Programming Course
video.description:
Take your Python skills to the next level with this intermediate Python course. First, you will get a review of basic concepts such as lists, strings, and dictionaries, but with an emphasis on some lesser known capabilities. Then, you will learn more advanced topics such as threading, multiprocessing, context managers, generators, and more.

💻 Code: https://github.com/python-engineer/python-engineer-notebooks/tree/master/advanced-python

🎥 Course from Patrick Loeber. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCbXgNpp0jedKWcQiULLbDTA

🔗 Written Tutorials from Patrick: https://www.python-engineer.com/courses/advancedpython/

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro
⌨️ (0:00:56) Lists
⌨️ (0:16:30) Tuples
⌨️ (0:29:49) Dictionaries
⌨️ (0:42:40) Sets
⌨️ (0:58:44) Strings
⌨️ (1:22:50) Collections
⌨️ (1:36:43) Itertools
⌨️ (1:51:50) Lambda Functions
⌨️ (2:04:03) Exceptions and Errors
⌨️ (2:20:10) Logging
⌨️ (2:42:20) JSON
⌨️ (2:59:42) Random Numbers
⌨️ (3:14:23) Decorators
⌨️ (3:35:32) Generators
⌨️ (3:53:29) Threading vs Multiprocessing
⌨️ (4:07:59) Multithreading
⌨️ (4:31:05) Multiprocessing
⌨️ (4:53:26) Function Arguments
⌨️ (5:17:28) The Asterisk (*) Operator
⌨️ (5:30:19) Shallow vs Deep Copying
⌨️ (5:40:07) Context Managers

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: 109 Hrishikesh Prakash
topLevelComment.text: In sets what's the difference between union and update?

replies.author: Pipit Gusmayanti
replies.text:
A.union(B) returns a new set object containing elements of set A and set B.
A.update(B) adds elements of set B to set A and doesn't return a new set object.

replies.author: Pipit Gusmayanti
replies.text:
sort() and reverse() mutates the original list and returns None.

nums = [1, 2, 3]
print(nums.sort()) # None
print(nums) # [3, 2, 1]

topLevelComment.text:
A thing to notice:
A list (set, tuple, or dict) that contains objects can't be copied with just copy() function. (It can be, but you will only copy references to objects, not objects itself)
So modification of an object in one list will affect another.
deepcopy function should be used for this king of copying.

topLevelComment.author: Shane Hung
topLevelComment.text:
Regards to content between 1:20:00 to 1:22:40, it mentioned about how F-string has the new format and old format. (older version and newer version of Python) 

However, it's confusing that the instructor didn't explain whether the new version of F-string may let programmer specify the decimal shows up in the print result: 

var = 3.1234567
var2 = 6
my_string = f"the variable is {var} and {var2}"
print (my_string)

This will show up as "the variable is 3.1234567 and 6." What if I want it to show up as 4-digit decimal for both ? (as "the valuable is 3.1234 and 6.0000) Does that mean I can only use older format for now?

replies.author: Shane Hung
replies.text: @Shubham saini Thank you so much!

replies.author: Shubham saini
replies.text:
I was also wondering this. No, the new f-strings also support specifying the number of decimal places. It would go similar to older formats like:
my_string = f"the variable is {var:.4f} and {var2:.4f}"

replies.author: Kaveen
replies.text:
@Jah Movement Empaya IMO 1) the most important use of Logging is to print the output into a file, which you cannot do with a normal print() statement. Also, logging is lightweight compared to pandas.export_to_csv() etc. 2) the second import use case is by managing the log levels (DEBUG, INFO, WARNING, etc.). For example: you might want to print onto console only the necessary output and hence you can set streamhandler to warning level (and above); on the other hand you might want to print every output onto a file and hence you can set filehandler to debug (and above).

The simplest technique is to start replacing print statements with loggers and you will see the benefits

replies.author: Christopher Smith
replies.text:
from multiprocessing import Process
import os
import time

def square_numbers():
    for i in range(100):
        i * i
        time.sleep(0.1)

processes = []
num_processes = os.cpu_count()

# create processes
for i in range(num_processes):
    p = Process(target=square_numbers)
    processes.append(p)

# start
for p in processes:
    p.start()

# join
for p in processes:
    p.join()

print("end main")

topLevelComment.author: moastlee
topLevelComment.text:
Really great video for interviews recap! Just want to point out one thing: it is not recommended to "share" value, i.e, memory, in multiprocessing procedure, because it is relatively inefficient to try to access a data from the RAM by different processors at the same time. In order to maximize the ability of the multiprocessing technique, you'll usually split a relatively large dataset into subsets, and hand each of the subsets to different processors and squeeze out all the calculation resource per processor to do whatever complex calculating process you want for the dataset, and finally merge all the sub-results back into the overall result (this is also why people say multiprocessing is for CPU-bound task). Therefore, using "Lock" for avoiding race conditions is actually "mimicking" threading behavior.

That being said, the multiprocessing module provides several data-exchange methods if your "data sharing" situation is actually for cross-process communication, or update a global factor for the rest of the processor to use.

There are a lot of details in the documentation of the python multiprocessing module, I basically just rephrase them with adding some of my experience in using these techniques in real life. Hope it is helpful!

replies.author: Naveen Boodoo
replies.text:
I ran into this same problem at first before learning that depending on the IDE, it auto-selects the wrong library.
It fills in "_collections" instead of "collections", which are 2 different things. Simply remove the underscore from the first and make sure the word "collections" is the exact word after "from".

WRONG: 

from _collections import Counter

CORRECT: 

from collections import Counter

This may not be your issue, however, but might be a possibility.

replies.author: Onion Sandwich
replies.text: ​@James A In most programs, you'd need constants - that are used throughout the program. Okay, so here's an example - I've recently designed a program for that needs a threshold percentage to indicate if a player is over-performing his capability. This number is used through the program in many a way. Till recently, I've set it at 82% (an example) - with COVID, players are now offered more rest - and now, validating 'em against the same threshold didn't make sense - I update the tuple from 82% to 61% (example) -- My code works the same way -- and I get the result I need. Tuples are static data - that's needed throughout your program -- very important.

topLevelComment.text: Why does my code say "Function 'sort' doesn't return anything"

replies.author: James A
replies.text: @The glowing one okay thank you

replies.author: The glowing one
replies.text:
Good to hear that you figured it out. But just so you understand the error for next time: The sort() method sorts *in place*, that means nothing will be returned and your object will be sorted. So list1.sort() means that the sort will be performed *on* list1.
There is also the sorted() function.
It is not a method and it returns a sorted object. 
To achieve the same as list1.sort() you can type list1 = sorted(list1)

For anyone new to Python who is curious, There's a way to shorten checking whether or not an element is in a list/tuple. Instead of

if "banana" in mylist:
    print("yes")
else:
    print("no")

, you can just use

print("banana" in mylist).

topLevelComment.author: Gleidonn
topLevelComment.text: Hello i wanted to ask, im a begginer i havent finished html and ccs basics and not even javascript. Should i be watching this? Or should i watch this, take notes for later on uses? Or should i just finish html and other things, also is java script worth learning?

replies.author: armstrongtixid
replies.text:
@Gleidonn It doesn't actually matter. HTML/CSS have nothing to do with Python, while JavaScript does have slightly similar syntax to Python, so it doesn't matter what order you learn it in. I know many people who started with HTML/CSS/JS and then moved on to Python. I myself started with Python and then moved on to HTML/CSS/JS. It really doesn't matter that much. I learnt them side by side (but started with Python) as well a bit. Learning HTML and CSS you can do whenever, but I suggest you do Python/JS before HTML/CSS, because many core programming concepts are in those two languages, versus HTML/CSS, which are only used in the web and have 0 logic. Therefore, I think you should learn either Python or JavaScript before the other two. I would suggest JavaScript, because the syntax is a lot like many other languages, while Python has quite unique syntax. If you learn JS first, you'll have 0 problems with Python. If you learn Python first, you may come across difficulties with JS. Therefore, my final answer is:

1. Learn JS
2. Learn Python
3. Learn HTML
4. Learn CSS

replies.author: Gleidonn
replies.text: Neil Dixit Thank you very much. But i should learn it in this order right? Html, ccs, java script and then python? I heard that every laungage or whetever is important right? So should i skip to python?

replies.author: armstrongtixid
replies.text: Yes. You don't need to know HTML/CSS/JS to do Python. This is an intermediate Python course, so you need to know the basic Python course (I'd recommend the one by Mike Dane's Giraffe Academy on this channel). HTML and CSS are worth learning for web development and design, as it's really useful. JavaScript is incredibly useful on the web as it makes the website actually do something, as it determines the behaviour of the website, while HTML defines the content of the website, and CSS how it looks (styling). JS is now useful outside of browsers and the web as well, with the creation of Node.js around 10 years ago, which seems to be the successor to Java (The most popular language for a long time). I suggest you check out a bit about Node.js. Happy programming!
